p: The verbena herb—blooming overground parts of the plant is characterized by the presence of several important groups of antioxidants–iridoids, phenylpropanoid glycosides, phenolic acids and flavonoids [ 6, 7, 8, 9, 10, 11, 12, 13, 14]. Iridoids are represented mainly by verbenalin, aucubin and hastatoside, while phenylpropanoid glycosides by verbascoside, isoverbascoside and eukovoside. In the group of phenolic acids, there are mainly ferulic acid, protocatechuic acid, and depsides—chlorogenic and rosmarinic acids, and dicaffeoylquinic acid derivatives. Flavonoids are represented by compounds commonly found in the plant kingdom—kaempferol, luteolin, and apigenin, however, some rare flavonoids like scutellarein and pedalitin are also found in the plant material. The plant produces an essential oil which is dominated by monoterpenoid components. Sterols, carbohydrates and numerous bioelements are also found in the herb [ 6, 7, 8, 9, 10, 11, 12, 13, 14].
